data.title: Gibson vs. Martin vs. Taylor acoustics
data.meta_description:
I'd love a higher end, American built acoustic guitar.  I know everyone has their preferences, and I think this issue has been discussed before.

I know...
data.text:
As with so many things there is no one correct answer here. Lore gets in the way. True objectivity is hard.

For myself the answe was to try to ascertain what in reality made a Martin sound the way I like. And look the way I like. And have the underlying quality the name stands for.

I found the answer for myself in an American made dreadnaught Martin that simply within itself bares the name "Custom," but was sold for a few years by a few dealerships (for whom I think they were solely built) under the name "MMV." -A name not found in Martin's catalog, nor on the guitars themselves.

It had solid indian rosewood sides and back, an ebony board (my own favorite) and the famed Martin cross bracing with a slight forward positioning. -In this much like, I believe, the later D-18s. (In truth I am not deep into Martin lore.) Spruce top. Pretty standard Martin badged hardware -- but here gold colored and a bit 'snazzier.'

It has a very open and balanced sound. Very "Martin" if you will, but a bit more even on the top.

MF was one of the dealers that sold them and I talked their sales rep into allowing me to get a posted discount (15%?) when the small print said that Martin guitars were not included in that offer.

I think I paid about $1250 new with a Martin hard case. I could easily sell for more than that now, though not so much as would a model that fits the "lore"

It does, though, have the full Martin lifetime (to the original owner) warranty. "Lore" or no, it is the real thing.

They sometime show up on ebay and/or reverb.

-don

As with so many things there is no one correct answer here. Lore gets in the way. True objectivity is hard.

For myself the answe was to try to ascertain what in reality made a Martin sound the way I like. And look the way I like. And have the underlying quality the name stands for.

I found the answer for myself in an American made dreadnaught Martin that simply within itself bares the name "Custom," but was sold for a few years by a few dealerships (for whom I think they were solely built) under the name "MMV." -A name not found in Martin's catalog, nor on the guitars themselves.

It had solid indian rosewood sides and back, an ebony board (my own favorite) and the famed Martin cross bracing with a slight forward positioning. -In this much like, I believe, the later D-18s. (In truth I am not deep into Martin lore.) Spruce top. Pretty standard Martin badged hardware -- but here gold colored and a bit 'snazzier.'

It has a very open and balanced sound. Very "Martin" if you will, but a bit more even on the top.

MF was one of the dealers that sold them and I talked their sales rep into allowing me to get a posted discount (15%?) when the small print said that Martin guitars were not included in that offer.

I think I paid about $1250 new with a Martin hard case. I could easily sell for more than that now, though not so much as would a model that fits the "lore"

It does, though, have the full Martin lifetime (to the original owner) warranty. "Lore" or no, it is the real thing.

They sometime show up on ebay and/or reverb.

View attachment 266023

View attachment 266021

View attachment 266022

-don

A RW dreadnaught with forward shifted braces has its roots in the pre-war D28, which is now the HD28, and the non scalloped forward shifted current standard D28 has its roots in the 50 and 60s D28 models that no longer had scalloped bracing. When I played the new standard D28, it was so much more responsive than the previous version, that I realized that the forward shifted braces had as much or maybe even more contribution to the ultra responsive and lively top, than scalloped braces have. The best of both worlds is obviously both forward shifted and scalloped, for the most responsive top. And, the HD35 is actually the liveliest of all because it has even lighter 1/4" scalloped braces, rather than the 5/16" ones on D28 models.

I am in the minority but Gibsons are wonderful. It’s just a plain working guitar and doesn’t have the boutique image of a Martin or Taylor.

I had a couple of really basic LG-0 parlor student guitars.

I know this will piss off @DougMen lol

No, I like them, but like all acoustics, and maybe even more so than Martins, every piece of wood is different, and Gibsons are very inconsistent, so there are J200s, J45s, Hummingbirds, Doves, Songwriters, Southern Jumbos, and LG-0s that are magic, are there are also some that are real dogs. This is once again speaking from personal experience, and from playing dozens of Gibson acoustics at the store over my 15 years working there, and over all different models in their range. Taylors are the most consistent and Gibsons the least so, with Martin in-between the two, but the very best Taylors never approach the magic of a really really good Martin or Gibson, IMO.

I find Taylor’s to be infinitely more playable than Martins - I’ve played a few Martins that are literally a battle between left hand and guitar. But nothing is more subjective than acoustic guitar preferences.

Martin just ships their guitars with higher action, because if it's too high for a player's taste, it's very simple to lower the saddle a bit by sanding down the bottom. If the saddle is too low for your taste, then you have to put a whole new saddle in. But, also, in relation to your comment, Taylor makes their guitars for electric players, while Martin makes theirs for acoustic players who aren't afraid to build up their strength to get the best sound AND playability from their guitar. On an acoustic, as on a Strat or Tele, the best tone is achieved with a bit higher action and a more aggressive attack, rather than the ultra low action and feather light touch used on a LP or shred style guitar.
